body: This is expected per [RFC - Allow All Directives in Line Comments ](https://github.com/eslint/rfcs/tree/main/designs/2019-allow-all-directives-in-line-comments). The solution is to change the comments (for example, we changed `// global...` to `// Global...` in PR https://github.com/eslint/eslint/pull/14656 which implemented the RFC).

> I did a quick check of the FB codebase and found _**200**_ comments which need to be updated.
> Many of them are "multiline singleline" comments:
> 
> ```js
> // this is the start of my comment which uses the word
> // global on the second line
> ```

@eslint/eslint-tsc thoughts about this? I'd be personally fine with reverting the change, as we might have underestimated the impact.

To be clear - I think this is a great change - but I think that something like what @aladdin-add suggested is a hard pre-requisite for the feature to disambiguate comments.

----

another example that's relatively common is for people to refer to "eslint" when explaining their usage of a disable comment:

```js
// eslint doesn't understand how to foo the bar
// eslint-disable-next-line plugin/foo-bar
```

I’m fine with reverting. It seems like the cost outweighs the added value. If we want to reintroduce at some point then I agree with @aladdin-add’s point that coming up with an unambiguous format is the right way to go.

body:
In today's TSC meeting, we decided to revert https://github.com/eslint/eslint/pull/14656 and not include this feature in the final release.

We might revisit allowing all directives as line comments in the future, but definitely not for ESLint v8.0.0.

Ah man, I was looking forward to this feature. 🙃

I [brought up](https://static.gosugamers.net/34/80/de/5c117393e1e233fb0bb57a50740269920ff2cb048b2fd853d8c62cb29b.png) this issue in the RFC, but it seems I was too late.

It would be nice if `eslint-*` directives could be supported, at least.

Will the RFC be reopened for further discussion?

Reverted in ESLint v8.0.0-beta.1

@bradzacher thanks for reporting this!
